texts.shortText: Forms flat growths consisting of a series of irregular sausage-like lobes that adhere strongly to the substratum. Colour dark green, sometimes brown tinged. Utricles cylindrical and about 1 mm long and 0.1 mm in diameter.
Lobes about 50 mm long and 5 mm thick, colonies up to 100 mm across.

Global: The species has a widespread distribution including Mozambique, Kenya, Australia and New Zealand, but the subspecies capense is endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Mozambique.
Grows in pools and on rocks in the mid-to low intertidal.

Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.

The flattened growth form is fairly unique among Western Cape species, but similar to the Creeping codium C. prostratum which occurs along the east coast. That species has a more tubular branching body form though.
